subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove
Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today I'd like to talk about the acquisition of siddhis.
That's the Sanskrit or yoga term for powers or attainments, accomplishments, that are
derived through ascetic disciplines in the practice of yoga.
There are many different kinds of siddhis that are enumerated in the yoga sutras and
elsewhere, but really, you can't put a limit on them at all, because something new could
always pop up.
For example, one siddhi is having super powers - well, they are all super powers - but one
might be like super hearing.
Nikola Tesla in his autobiography writes about how as a child, he had super hearing and it
was disturbing.
It was considered a pathology for which there was no diagnosis nor a cure.
People thought he would amount to nothing, because if a fly were to land in the room,
it would sound to him like a loud thud.
He could hear people talking several rooms away.
Sometimes he said that the rumbling of a train passing by miles away was incredibly disturbing
to him.
It seemed like perhaps he was hysterical or psychotic or something.
He just couldn't stand sounds.
Now, many of you will know the name Nikola Tesla.
Others may not.
He's one of the great inventors in human history.
He's the man who invented, amongst other things, alternating current, the kind of electricity
that powers our houses now all over the world.
He managed - I think it's fair to say - to take this unusual siddhi that came to him
spontaneously as a child, perhaps as a result of what we could call karma, but he managed
to transform it into his incredible creativity.
It’s said of Tesla, that as a creative engineer and scientist, when he created a map they
came fully formed in his mind, a diagram for a new invention or a device.
He would write it out or draw it as it appeared in his mind spontaneously, or through an effort
of concentration, and it would work perfectly the first time.
I've heard that as well from Lynn Charlson, who was an inventor who helped finance the
Intuition Network many years ago.
He is the man who invented power steering and the hydraulic motor.
The same thing, the inventions come to him fully formed in the mind and then they work
right away the first time.
I think, with regard to the hydraulic motor, it works so well that for decades and decades
there was no need for further Improvement on it.
That's an example of people using this kind of attainment or power in a practical way
for the benefit of humanity, in both cases, inventions.
But, it doesn't always work out for the success of the individual who has the siddhis.
I studied Ted Owens for 10 years and he's a man who demonstrated remarkable powers of
precognition or you could say even psychokinesis.
There's always a small controversy, “Did he predict this event or did he cause it?”
But in either case, was he successful as a human being?
I think if you were to ask him he'd say, “Yes” - because he lived his own life, he pursued
his own sense of integrity.
There are people alive today who consider him a prophet or a saint.
But, from any conventional standpoint in terms of his ability to support his family, his
ability to raise his children, and his ability to maintain stable relationships, one might
say that his life was not a success, in fact, anything but.
So, these powers are not necessarily of benefit to people.
In fact, sometimes they're considered an enormous irritation.
People would like them to go away.
Now, I can't tell you what you want to do with regard to the acquisition or attainment
of these abilities.
You'll hear many spiritual teachers say to pay no attention to them whatsoever, they’re
a distraction.
You certainly don't want to get ego attached to them.
Although I can tell you, Ted Owens was very ego attached.
There are many great psychics who are ego attached and happy to demonstrate, on command,
the various powers or siddhis that they have.
You’re going to get advice from all sides.
There are the tantric practitioners who feel that the acquisition of siddhis is the goal
of spiritual practice.
What I can talk about is simply how it works for me.
I can say this, I’m pretty bad at demonstrating any kind of psychic ability on demand.
Yet, I would say that my life has been full of magical and psychic occurrences.
Sometimes they're literally life-saving.
I talked in a previous “In Presence” segment about the time I was playing with magic and
ended up being confronted with people who threw a knife at me and said that they were
about to kill me.
It was at that moment, when quite spontaneously, I was filled - I can only describe it as like
the spirit of Jesus Christ - because I stood up bare naked in front of these hostile people
with a sense of pure serenity and peace about me.
They just slithered away with their tails between their legs, if I can mix metaphors
there.
So, I think if you were to follow my advice for what it's worth, I would say it's useful.
It‘s very useful to appreciate and to celebrate these things when they occur, but not to expect
them or to demand them or to promise them to anybody.
The real key as I understand it with regard to siddhis - I take my guidance from the great
Austrian mystic Rudolf Steiner - who said, “Take two steps towards developing your
character before you take one step toward knowledge and power.”
Because in a way, the development of your character is the whole key to acquiring siddhis.
You see, if your word is always good.
If you always mean what you say and say what you mean and follow up with everything that
you say so that your word is impeccable, well then, that impeccable word I would say reaches
out into the universe - that impeccable word of yours, your character.
And things happen, because you are a person of integrity.
It reminds me of the story of the great Hasidic master who is known as the Baal Shem Tov,
which means the master of the good name.
What does that mean?
When he says something, it happens.
Of course, an entire religious movement, Hebrew Hasidism, was built around that, and I shared
a little bit in a previous segment concerning my great-uncle Harry, who left me with his
favorite book, which was the Yiddish version of Tales of the Baal Shem Tov.
I’ve referred to him again in another segment of the “In Presence” series when I talk
about flying chariots, because according to legend, the Baal Shem Tov had a horse and
carriage that would fly over the treetops at night with his disciples as they went on
various magical journeys.
But my point is this: master of the good name, it means that he is able to speak words of
truth and when he says them, they happen.
How do you become the master of the good name or master of the holy name, the one who can
say the name of God and make it happen, the one whose consciousness and whose prayers
rise to the highest heaven, where they can be heard by the greatest of Gods, the Lord
of all the Gods one might say, Adonai Elohim in Hebrew?
It requires a purity of soul.
It requires solidity of character.
Those are really the qualities that help encourage the cultivation of siddhis in my estimation.
The thing is this, they're great when they come.
I certainly never expected to be filled with what I'm calling the spirit of Jesus Christ
at a moment when I really needed it, but there it was.
Of course I can't promise anything to even myself that this will ever happen again or
need ever happen again.
But I can say this, I'm open to them when they come.
I delight in them when they come.
I expect them.
I’ve lived long enough to know that we live in a magical world.
I'm sharing this with you now because I think my way is a good way.
It's worked very well for me and I'm speaking now as a man in my seventies.
I've lived a few decades.
I've been around the block a few times.
While there's no reason you should follow what worked for me - It may not work for you
at all - but on the other hand I delight in it.
It works for me very well and I'm happy to share that with you.
You do with it as you may.
-- But let me close by asking you this question.
When have you experienced siddhis in your life?
How meaningful were they to you?
How quickly did you forget about them?
How well are you able to integrate them and will you be prepared for the next one that's
coming your way?
Thank you for being with me.
